entry.title: pWnOS: 2.0
entry.content:
Image: pWnOS: 2.0 (Pre-Release)

Nmap output:

Nikto output:

There is a SQL injection in email, we can see an error message trying to log in (filling an email field with the single quote):

Using Sqlmap we dump the whole databases:

We try to crack hashes but without success in the reasonable time:

With OS Shell functionality of Sqlmap (–os-shell), we was able to obtain shell with the web user privileges:

As we can see, MySQL daemon is running as root (=uid 0), this is also the reason, why we were able to write something with database user to /var/www (owned by www-data), that’s not common.

We can also upload weevely to the remote system and use it as the more sophisticated shell:

We found the database credentials, however they didn’t work:

That was strange, because the web application is connected. After a little more digging, we found this suspicious file:

The blog application uses the text files instead of MySQL. We were only able to locate the password file, without cracking it:

Using root / root@ISIntS we can finally log in via ssh as root:

entry.title: pWnOS: 1.0
entry.content:
Image: pWnOS: 1.0

Nmap output:

After a while of browsing the web page, we found trivial LFI vulnerability:

We can find a lot of information querying the samba service too:

There are a few enumeration modules in metasploit:

The webmin is vulnerable and the exploit in metasploit:

Basically the exploitation could be performed on command line to disclose arbitrary file, for example:

Using john on /etc/shadow, we obtain credentials of user vmware for successful login to the system:

The box could be rooted using standard vmsplice exploit.

However, there is another way to get user account. The script dowkd.pl ensures us that the OpenSSL is vulnerable (CVE-2008-0166).

We download and unpack already generated RSA keys from offensive-security repository:

Because usage of weak private keys could be blacklisted on our server, we use the following instructions to enable them.

Basically adding this directive to our ssh_config file should be sufficient:

In exploitdb, we use python script to try every possible private key:
